intro: Galium mexicanum var. asperulum, commonly known as Mexican bedstraw, is a perennial herb native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes many shrubs and herbs with opposite leaves and small flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its stems are usually prostrate or ascending, and it produces small, white or greenish flowers in clusters. The leaves are opposite, simple, and often have a rough or hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance.
